loans.name: Liberatha

texts.en:
Liberatha is 27 years old. She is married to a mason and has five children who are between five and sixteen years old. All of her children go to school. Liberatha has a beauty salon for ladies and she has run this business for ten years. She would like to get a loan to buy more beauty products, such as hair care and styling products, to sell.

Liberatha says the profit from this business will be used to buy a motorbike to help with transportation. She hopes to have a business valued at over a million Rwandan francs in the future.  

One of Liberatha's clients is seen in this picture. She agreed to have her photo taken while having her hair done at Liberatha's salon.

loans.use: To buy more beauty products to sell.

loans.name: Kungkear

texts.en:
Mrs. Kungkear C., 48, is a widow with one son who is a security guard. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, capital of Cambodia.

Kungkear is a farmer; she grows ginger on her farmland in the village where she lives. She is requesting her first loan of US$700 to purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain her ginger farm.

Pictured: Mrs. Kungkear is at home, not at the farm

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain her ginger farm

loans.name: Denyse

texts.en: Denyse is 32 years old and married to a house constructor. They have one child who is one year old. Denyse sells beans and vegetables and she has had this business for a period of ten years. She would like to get a loan to buy more beans and vegetables to sell. With the profit, she hopes to build her own store to save her from paying expensive rent for her business. In the future she would like to increase her loan amount.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables and beans to sell.

loans.name: Him

texts.en: Mrs. B. is a 50-year-old widowed mother. She has a small shop in the local market in Phnom Penh City. She always gets up early in the morning in order to travel to the place that sells vegetables in bulk, then she brings them to retail to people who come to the market. B. has two children, one of whom (a son) repairs vehicles to earn a living, while the remaining one is jobless. To accrue a daily profit, B. hopes to expand her vegetable business by investing a Kiva loan as capital. Any remaining cash from the loan, B. will use to contribute to her son for buying more vehicle spare parts to perform his repairing service.

loans.use: To expand her vegetable business.

loans.name: Virgincita

texts.en:
Virgincita G. is from the village of Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 55 years old. Virgincita is separated from her spouse and has one school-aged child. Virgincita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods, and junk foods in the local community. Virgincita has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Virgincita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virgincita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Virgincita is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Virgincita from HSPFI and she chose to have this loan amount. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is married with four children aged between 10 and 14 years.She does mixed farming in her hometown of Nyamira in Western Kenya producing tea, vegetables, sugarcane, and milk and sells at the local market and to government institutions.

She has applied for this loan of 45,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a dairy cow. She hopes the family income will improve. She wants to buy more land in future.She gains additional income from a cereals business in the local market.

Animal diseases remain her greatest challenge.

loans.use: Purchase and insurance of a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 22-year-old single man living with his parents and one brother. In 2003, he opened a small car repair shop. He works independently in his business. He repairs different type of cars and works hard to cover the increasing costs of food, housing, and other family expenses. His income is needed to help his father to meet the needs of the family. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to improve his business level and purchase needed tools to attract more clients. In the future, he is planning to expand his shop and add a new service by selling car oil.

loans.use: to improve his business level and purchase needed tools

loans.name: Moun

texts.en:
Mrs. Moun M. (in the photo with her loom) and her husband, Mr. Chorm Kheun, have been married since 1970 and have five children--one son and four daughters. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. 

Moun has been a silk weaver since she was 15 years old. She sells her finished products to a middleman, who then takes them to sell in the market in Phnom Penh. She is asking for a loan of $300 to purchase weaving materials to continue her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase weaving materials to continue her weaving business

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel E. is 26 years old, married, and supports her family by operating two business ventures: a general store and a fish vending business. She lives in Purok 1, Brgy. Culipapa, Hinobaan, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living condition with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts.

By working hard in her general store and fish vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000. Maricel is now borrowing PHP 10,000 so that she can continue to purchase more stock to sell. This will be her 9th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 16,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Maricel aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Antonieta

texts.en:
Antonieta F. is a married woman who lives in Purok 1, Brgy. Culipapa, Hinobaan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  fishing and fish-selling businesses. Her husband Elmer F., who is 40 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have two children who are 8 and 17 years old. 

Antonieta joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1998 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 16 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Antonieta has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 20,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 17th loan, she is borrowing PHP 20,000, which she intends to buy materials for the fishing boat so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Antonieta F. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase materials for the fishing boat

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia V. is from the village of Lagonglong, Misamis Oriental. She is 58 years old. Lilia is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Lilia runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods and snacks in the local community. Lilia has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Lilia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Lilia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to buy and sell. Lilia is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be the fourth loan taken by Lilia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Tuliya Group

texts.fr: Ushindi B. M.  est  présidente du groupe Tuliya, âgée de 31 ans, mariée, mère de 7 enfants.  Son mari est  vendeur des pommes de terre.  Elle vend aussi de pommes de terre comme son conjoint. Elle  commença son business  avec son fonds propre, reçu de leur tontine  une somme de 300$, plus tard, elle bénéficia de crédit de l’IMF  Hekima. Elle installe ses produits  dans un dépôt – marché - secteur Nyabushongo.  Il y a 9 ans qu’elle exerce ce business. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  avec  5 sacs de pommes de terre, le reste pour  l’épargne. En plus, elle ambitionne acheter une parcelle et construire une belle maison, plus tard acheter un véhicule de transport de ses marchandises.  La cliente Ushindi B. M. remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique.  Il sied de signaler que ce groupe Tuliya est  composé de 36 membres.
texts.en: Ushindi B. M., the president of the Tuliya group, is 31 years old, married, and a mother of seven children.   Her husband sells potatoes and she sells potatoes as his spouse. She began this business with her own capital, 300$, raised through her tontine. Later she benefitted from a loan from Hekima. She installs her products in a warehouse within the Nyabushongo sector market.  She has conducted her business for nine years. This new loan should help her stock up with five sacks of potatoes and the rest will be savings. In addition, she hopes to buy a plot and build a beautiful home and later, to buy a transport vehicle for her merchandise. This client, Ushindi B. M., thanks Hekima for its actions that help the poor who are excluded from traditional banking. It should be noted that this Tuliya group is composed of 36 members.

loans.use: Five sacks of potatoes and the rest for savings

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Peou

texts.en:
Peou Y. is 74-year-old widow who currently lives in Phnom Penh City. Her husband died of senility years ago. She is the mother of four children; two are married and the other two are single. She has a life partner who works in various occupations and has a fixed salary per month.

Peou Y. is a housewife. She works in and around her house caring for her children, cooking meals, cleaning house and managing things. Peou Y. is now concerned that her house is getting old and some parts are broken down so that it is not comfortable for her family. To solve this problem, Peou Y. would like to request a loan to repair the broken down part of her house.

loans.use: To repair the broken part of her house

loans.name: Simorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Simorn C. (in the photo with her loom), and her husband, Mr. Soeun Seng, live on an island in the Mekong River, which is about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have four sons--two are in school and other two are still young.

Mrs. Simorn is a weaver. Her husband is in construction. Because the weaving business is a traditional profession and she does not want to change to another business, she is asking for another loan of $200 to purchase weaving materials for  her business.

loans.use: To purchase weaving materials for her weaving business

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane L. is a married woman who lives in Purok 1, Brgy. Culipapa, HInobaan, Negros Occidental.  She earns her living by operating 2 business ventures:  fishing and a fish selling business.  Her husband Randolf, who is 42 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities.  

They have four children who are between the ages of 2 to 16 years old.  Mary Jane joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Mary Jane has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow.  Her previous loan of PHP 13,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 20,000, increasing the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 14th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to buy fishing gears and equipment for the fishing boat so that she could continue to save up for the future education of her children.  Mary Jane L. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase fishing gear and equipment.

loans.name: Koeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Koeun M. (pictured in the photo with her husband), 35, and her husband, Mr. Soeun Kerk, 31, have been married since 2000 and have three sons--two are in school and another one is still young. They live in a village about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.  

Mrs. Koeun M. and her husband are fishermen, and they are vegetable farmers as well. She is asking for her first loan of $1,000 to renovate the house where she lives.

loans.use: To renovate the house where she lives

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.en:
Beatriz A. is a hardworking entrepreneur who is always looking for opportunities to grow her business. Through her daily effort, she is bringing her family more hope. 

Over time, she has been able to purchase a fishing boat for her husband to manage and use for fishing. Meanwhile, she is the one who sells his fish directly to people in the local community and the nearby town of Binangonan, Rizal.

The fishing business has brought happiness to Beatriz’s family. Because of its profits, she has been able to support her family’s needs. It has also provided her a way to pay for her only son’s education until college.

Beatriz is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders to purchase an additional fishing cage (fish trap) to catch more fish to sell. This will help their business grow and make more profit, which will enable her to attain her goals in life.

loans.use: To buy additional fish traps to catch more fish to sell.

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en: Mary Ann T. is 51 years old, married, and supports her family by operating a carinderia (eatery). She lives in Purok 1, Brgy. 1, Sipalay City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her carinderia (eatery), she is gradually gaining more economically stability for her family. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 15,600. Mary Ann is now borrowing PHP 23,000 so that she can continue to fund the operations of her food products. This will be her 11th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 20,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Mary Ann aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon--a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.

loans.use: Fund the operations of her carinderia (eatery)

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 21-year-old single man living with his parents. Despite his young age, he is a proud new business owner; he has opened a car spare parts and car electricity shop. He currently owns his business and started it in 2009. He is working hard to build a good business reputation due to his short business period.  

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l.  to increase his inventory of spare parts and add  more needed tools. He hopes to open a bigger store to sell spare parts in the future. He told us that he would like one day to open a commerciA. center.

loans.use: to increase his inventory of spare parts and add more needed tools

loans.name: Sophy

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophy P. and her husband, Mr. Sok Men, live in a suburb of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have two daughters, one of them is a garment factory worker and the other one attends school. Her husband is a pedicab driver.

Sophy stays at home and does housework. The main source of income is from her daughter’s salary. She is asking for a loan of $500 to build a restroom for the  family’s use, and to connect her house to a private water and electricity utility service.

loans.use: To build a restroom and connect house to water & electricity service.

loans.name: Nguon

texts.en:
Nguon S., 43 years old, is a humble villager living in Takhmao city, in the middle of Cambodia. She is married and blessed with five children. Her husband is a fisherman who fishes to feed his family and to sell as well. 

To earn a living, Nguon S. sells many kinds of flowers, which she either grows herself or buys in bulk from her supplier. Her husband helps her when she needs to pick up the flowers. Unfortunately, their motorbike often has broken down during use. Because of that, Nguon S. has decided to seek a loan of $600 from Kiva, which she will use to replace the broken motorcycle.

loans.use: To replace a broken motorcycle

location.town: Spean Krong Village, Kampong Thom Province

loans.name: Florencia

texts.en: Florencia C. is a married woman who lives in Purok 1, Brgy. Talacdan, Cauayan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: buying and selling charcoal/firewood, and selling rice. Her husband, Leonardo, who is 62 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have four children who are between 26 and 36 years old. Florencia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past 16 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Florencia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,300, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 17th loan, she is borrowing PHP 18,000, which she intends to use for additional capital for firewood/charcoal to sell and to buy a vehicle so that she can continue to save up for future savings and expansion of her business. Florencia C. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon--a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase a vehicle for charcoal delivery

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sonida

texts.en:
Mrs. Sonida S. is 27 years old and her husband, Mr. Veng Khy, is 23 years old.  They have been married since 2009 and have a young son. The family lives on an island on the Mekong River about 15 km. from Phnom Penh City. 

Sonida and her husband are weavers. In addition, her husband is also a fisherman. Sonida had asked for a Kiva loan once before, she is now asking for another loan of $700 to purchase weaving materials to continue her weaving business, and to buy a boat for her husband.

loans.use: To purchase weaving materials, and buy a fishing boat

loans.name: Meng

texts.en:
Meng Thids is 30 years old and married to 31-year-old Oreim Sum, who helps support the family by running a motor taxi. Meng Thids is devoted to her two children, who are students in the local public school. 

She earns an income by selling  fruit in the local market. This couple can make a profit of approximately $13 per day to support their family. Currently, Meng T. always needs to hire a taxi when she needs transportation. To reduce the cost of transportation, she would like to borrow some funds in order to buy a used motorbike.

loans.use: To buy a used motorbike

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita T. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Carpo, Brgy. Casay, Dalaguete, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a Sari-Sari (general) store. Her husband, Aurelio T., is 57 years old, works as a Carpenter to earn his living, and helps his wife with her business. They have one child who is 20 years old. Lolita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 5 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Lolita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 14,000, increasing her family's standard of living. This time, for her 6th loan, she is borrowing PHP 11,000, which she intends to use to pay for more stock to sell, so that she can continue to save up for her family's future. Lolita T. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Samon

texts.en: Mrs. Samon S. and her husband, Mr. Yi Yoeun, have been married since 1978 and have 8 children - 6 sons and 2 daughters. Samon is a weaver and her husband is a farmer. She is requesting a loan of $350 to provide capital for her husband to purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain his farm.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Gilda

texts.en:
Gilda T. is a married woman who lives in Purok Kenon, Brgy. 7, Isabela, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating 3 businesses: food production/sales, a general store and an entertainment business. Her husband, Larry T., is 49 years old and works as a laborer to earn his living. He also helps in his wife's business activities. They have three children aged between 19 and 24 years old. Gilda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1997 because she hoped for something better for her family. With the help of her past 18 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Gilda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 29,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, raising the family's standard of living. This time, for her 19th loan, she is borrowing PHP 30,000, which she intends to use to buy more stock for the general store and spices for her food production business. She wants to continue to save up for her children's future education and for home appliances. Gilda T. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: to fund operations of her businesses

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en: Jacqueline M. is 30 years old. She is not married but she cares for four children who are her sisters - two of the children attend school. Jacqueline has been selling vegetables, including onions and peanuts, as well as cooking oil for the past six years. She needs this loan to buy more vegetables to sell. From the profits, she would like to build her own business location instead of paying rent.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Neang

texts.en: Mrs. Neang H. and her husband, Mr. Soeun Kong, live on an island in the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have one daughter. Neang and her husband run a store at home. She previously asked for a Kiva loan. She is applying for another loan of $1,000 to continue expanding her business by purchasing weaving materials (cotton thread) for resale.

loans.use: to purchase weaving materials (cotton thread) for resale

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en:
Jessica is from the village of Centro Napu, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 47 years old. She is separated and has one adult-aged child. To make a living, Jessica owns and operates retail store. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from her work.

In 2008, Jessica joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities.
Jessica is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used for additional capital for her retail store. Jessica plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. She will use some of the revenue to meet her family's basic needs, and save some for future use and house renovations.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For additional capital for her retail store.

loans.name: Marie Rose

texts.en: Marie Rose is 35 years old. She is married to a businessman who sells cooking oil. She has five children who are between the ages of four and fifteen years old. All her children attend school. Marie Rose sells vegetables and has been doing so for a period of fifteen years. She needs a loan to buy more tomatoes, carrots and peas. She says that her business is important because it helps her to finance needed expenditures for the well-being of her family. Marie Rose plans to use the profits from her business to pay for school fees. She dreams of being a wholesaler in the future.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Uk

texts.en: Mrs. Uk B. is 45 and the mother of two children. One of her children is already married and the other one is single. The children are employed and share in the responsibilities of the family. Uk B. stays at home to complete her daily routine, which includes cooking and caring for her kids.  She very much relies on the income from her husband’s work - he drives a motor taxi. He normally provides this service every day with his old motorcycle. Uk B. is taking out her loan to replace her husband's taxi as it breaks down frequently.

loans.use: To replace a taxi.

loans.name: Jeaneth

texts.en:
Jeaneth B. is from the village of Malipayon, Pangantucan, Bukidnon. She is 51 years old. Jeaneth is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Jeaneth owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks & other delicacies such as rice cakes, banana & camote cue as well as Filipino delicasies such as kutsinta & bibingka in the local community. Jeaneth has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Jeaneth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Jeaneth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Jeaneth is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional raw ingredients & working capital. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Jeaneth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional raw ingredients & working capital.

loans.name: Jeannette

texts.en: Jeannette is 26 years old and married to a wholesaler who sells peas. She has two children who are between the ages of one and six. None of her children are enrolled in school yet. Jeannette sells peas and beans in bulk and she has been doing this for a period of six years. Her business is prospering and Jeanette has decided to request this loan to buy more beans to sell.  She hopes to renovate her house from the expected profits. She says that her business succeeds because she manages to pay rent for her business as well as pay for other basic needs. She would like to be a sole distributor of peas in the future.

loans.use: To buy more peas and beans to sell.

loans.name: Esperanza

texts.en:
Esperanza D. is from the village of Bangahan, Pangantucan, Bukidnon. She is 56 years old. Esperanza is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Esperanza owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from making and selling breads & pastries, such as otap & piaya, in the local community. Esperanza has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Esperanza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Esperanza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Esperanza is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional raw ingredients & working capital. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Esperanza from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional raw ingredients & working capital.

loans.name: Joselyne

texts.en: Joselyne M. is 26 years old. She is married to a plumber and has two children who are between the ages of seven and nine. All her children go to school. Joselyne owns a lady’s salon and she has had the business for seven years. She has requested this loan to buy more beauty products, hair relaxer and hair conditioner to use in her salon. She anticipates being able to buy a house from her profits in the future, which will reduce the expense of renting. All the people in this picture agreed to have their photo taken with Joselyne, who is attending to her client.

loans.use: To buy more beauty products to sell.

loans.name: Alexia

texts.en: Alexia is 38 years old. She is married and has six children who are between the ages of three and fourteen. Her husband sells hardware. Alexia has a beauty salon and sells hair products and cosmetics. She has had this business for thirteen years. She has requested a loan to buy more beauty products to sell and with the profits she would like to expand her house. She says that her business is successful because she repaid the previous loan and managed to save and raise school fees for her children. She would like to get a loan of 500,000RWF in the future. Alexia has been photographed combing her client's hair.  All those pictured here have agreed to have their picture taken with her.

loans.use: To buy more beauty products and cosmetics to sell.

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mom S. is a 42-year-old married woman who lives in Takhmao City. She owns a piece of land that she inherited from her grandmother. She grows different kinds of crops on her land, such as cabbages, cucumbers and morning glories, which she sells every two or three months when the plants mature. 

Mom S.'s husband is a construction worker in and around her community. The couple has four children; all of them are single. 

Mom S.'s motorbike is old and she needs to repair it very often. Because her savings account is not enough to buy a new motorbike, she is requesting some money to add to her personal savings so that she can buy a new motorbike to replace the broken one.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike to replace the broken one

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith R. is from the village of Barangay 17, Gingoog City. She is 47 years old. Judith is widowed and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Judith owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling green bananas in the local community. She also makes and sells sausage or longganisa. Judith has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Judith joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Judith has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase ingredients. Judith is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be the second loan taken out by Judith from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is 35 years old and married to a businessman. They have two children who are two and seven years old. One of her children goes to school.

Alice sells vegetables such as peas, tomatoes and beans. She has been in this business for ten years. She would like to get this loan to buy more vegetables to sell. The profit from this business will be used for savings and to construct a house. 

Her business has allowed her to do many things, like paying school fees for her children. She dreams of having a loan amount of one million Rwandan francs in the future.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Ton

texts.en:
Mrs. Ton S. has spent her life cultivating different types of crops, a skill she had learned from her grandparents when she was young. In addition, she sells a few snack foods to kids in front of her home. Ton S. is married and has five kids. One of her children is married and other four single. Her husband helps to share responsibilities by working in the construction field. 

Ton S. owns a motorcycle that she can use to provide the family transportation or pick up vegetables to sell. Unfortunately, it is now getting old and often breaks down during use. To resolve this problem, Ton S. decided to ask for a loan from Kiva in the amount of $1200 to renovate her old motorbike.

loans.use: To renovate her old motorbike

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 33-year-old married man living with his wife and two children. He is the main income provider for his family. He has eight years of experience working as a farmer. He has been running his own farm since 2007. He cultivates bananas and citrus fruit. He uses plastic tents to grow his produce. These tents also allow him to better monitor product quality as well as grow his products for more months during the year. He works independently in his business and he delivers his harvest with his van to local vegetable markets. Today, he is requesting a loan of $1200 to purchase needed supplies such as fertilizers for his agricultural work.

loans.use: purchase needed supplies for his agricultural work

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Liliane

texts.en:
Liliane is 28 years old and married to a farmer. She has two children who are five and eight years old. Both her children go to school. Liliane sells sweet potatoes and cassava; she has had this business for nine years. 

The loan will be used to buy more sweet potatoes and cassava. She believes that her business will make a good profit, and with this she will build a store for her business to save on the cost of renting. She would like to attain a working capital of one million Rwandan francs in the future.

loans.use: To buy more sweet potatoes and cassava to sell

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia A. is from the village of Tambagan, Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 54 years old. Cecilia is widowed and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Cecilia owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods & junk foods in the local community. Cecilia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Cecilia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cecilia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Cecilia is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Cecilia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary W. M. is forty-eight years old, married, and has four children aged between twenty-four and six years old. Her business is located at Mwingi town and is served by Thika Branch. Thika is the region in Kenya known for its production of pineapples. She has been selling baby accessories which include diapers, wet wipes, baby shirts etc. She sells mostly to the local people. 

She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is financial constraints. However she works very hard to keep her business going well. She is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more diapers, plastic pants and baby shirts to expand her business and meet the demand of her customers. She hopes to grow her business to wholesale status in future. She describes herself as creative, innovative, time conscious and aggressive.

loans.use: Diapers, plastic pants and baby shirts

loans.name: Run

texts.en:
Mr. Run V. is 37-year-old widower who currently lives in the best territory of Takhmao city, in Cambodia. He is a local chef. He is always hired by neighbors to cook meals for their wedding parties and their other ceremonies. Additionally he plants rice crops on the farmland he owns. 

Run V. faces difficulties traveling as he doesn’t have a vehicle to serve his daily transportation needs. He wants to own a motorcycle and is requesting a Kiva loan in order to purchase a second-hand motorcycle. This will allow to Run V. cut down on the expense of hiring taxis.

loans.use: To purchase a second-hand motorcycle

loans.name: Belencita

texts.en:
Belencita L. is from Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 43 years old. Belencita is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Belencita owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods & junk foods in the local community. Belencita has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Belencita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Belencita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Belencita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Belencita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Jean Marie Vianney

texts.en:
Jean Marie Vianney is 27 years old and is married with four children between the ages of 2 months and 15 years. His wife is a nurse. Jean Marie Vianney has been in this business for 2 years and sells juice, water, notebooks and other items.  He runs a very well organized store and is open from 7am until 8pm every day.

Jean Marie Vianney has requested a loan from Kiva via Vision Finance Company in order to expand his business through purchasing more goods. He believes that by purchasing more goods he will be able to attract more customers to his store.

loans.use: To purchase more stock

loans.name: Melagresa

texts.en:
Melagresa T. is from the village of Kandiis, Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. She is 49 years old. Melagresa is single. To make a living, Melagresa owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling lotions, perfumes & deodorants from NATASHA & AVON in the local community. Melagresa has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Melagresa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melagresa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Melagresa is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Melagresa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Wachiya

texts.en:
C. Wachiya is 37 years old and is married to Josphine Chebet, who is a house wife. C. supports a family of 5 people including his wife and children. His children are aged between 12 years and 4 years. He runs a hotel in a Kabarnet town and this has been his business for the last 5 years. He earns a monthly income of kshs 60,000.

C. has borrowed a loan of kshs 40,000 for his third loan with KADET after successfully paying the previous loans. He will add this loan amount to part of his income to buy ten goats for slaughter and wheat flour for his business. This will enable him meet the overhead cost of the business. He hopes this investment will bring in good profits so that he can use it to open another hotel in a different location.

He hopes is to buy a plot and build rental houses and also diversify his business to home products wholesale within the next two years. He would want to give his children the best education he can afford.

loans.use: To purchase food stock

loans.name: Teresia

texts.en:
Teresia P. is a 40-year-old single woman and the mother of two children. Teresia has been in the hotel business for the last year in Mombasa and it has been a success so far.

This is her first loan from KADET and she plans to stock up on foodstuffs such as onions, tomatoes, rice, and flour and to buy extra seats and tables. She anticipates that the addition to her business will bring in a boom and enable her to use the profits to renovate the hotel floors. Her dream is to succeed in life and take her children to the best schools.

loans.use: to purchase food stock, extra seats and tables

loans.name: Kimanzi

texts.en:
Kimanzi M. is twenty-eight years old and married. His wife runs their retail shop and they have one child aged one year old to whom they hope to give good education up to the university level. 

His business is located at Mwingi and he is served by the Thika Branch. Thika is the region in Kenya known for its production of pineapples. He has been selling cow and goat skins. He sells to other traders who sell them wholesale for making leather. He has been in this business for the last ten years now. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is financial constraints. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. 

He is using his loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more skins to resell to the traders. He hopes to grow his business and become the major skins distributor in the area. He also sees himself buying a car.  He describes himself as sociable and persuasive.

loans.use: Animal skins

loans.name: John Omondi

texts.en:
John Omondi O. is 24 years old and single. He lives in Lumakanda in Eldoret, Kenya and has been operating a motorcycle transportation business for the past 3 years. He earns a monthly profit of KES 5,000.

John learned about KADET LTD through a marketing awareness program in the area and he is applying for his third loan of KES 48,000 from KADET LTD. He intends to buy a new motorbike for his business and employ someone to ride it for him. He anticipates profits which he plans to use to open a retail shop in town. 
In the future, John wishes to have a pick-up to use for transportation. His deeper desire is to live a comfortable life.

loans.use: to buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Francoise

texts.en:
Francoise is 29 years old, married, and has one child who is one year old. Francoise is well-known in the food business in her area. She sells foods such as beans, rice, and Irish potatoes.  She has spent five years working in this business and works from 6 am to 7 pm.

Francoise struggles to make a profit and believes that she is unable to satisfy her customers' needs. A small amount of additional capital would help her business to grow.

Francoise has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to purchase a large quantity of additional goods which, hopefully, will satisfy the demand of her customers and increase her sales. If she is successful, Francoise will be able to build her business and a secure a future for her family.

loans.use: To purchase more  sugar, rice, and beans

loans.name: Fortunee

texts.en:
Fortunee is 28 years old and is married with one child, who is three years old.  No one else works in her family.  Fortunee's store is open from 5am until 8pm and she has a clean and well-stocked store selling local traditional beer. She has been in this business for four years.

Fortunee has requested a loan from Kiva lenders in order to grow her business. Fortunee will hopefully earn more profits, which in turn will allow her to reinvest in her business so that her revenue can keep growing. If successful, Fortunee will continue taking care of her children by providing more food for them as well as building a secure future for them.

loans.use: To purchase more local traditional beer

loans.name: Everline

texts.en:
Everline is a resident of Nyamira Town in western Kenya. She has been doing mixed farming for three years. Her challenge remains limited animal feeds. She has no other source of income. She has three children and two already attend school.

She has applied for this loan of 50,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo. This is her second loan; the first one was for 40,000 KES. With the added income, she plans to pay school fees and improve her children's standard of living.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Morine Jahenda

texts.en:
Morine Jahenda E. is a hardworking 32-year-old woman. She is married to Harun Kitui, a driver, and together they have two children ages 8 and 10 years old .She has been operating a green grocery business for about five years and she earns a monthly income of KES 4,000.

She learned about KADET LTD and joined. She had no previous credit history with any other MFI. She has now applied for her first loan of KES. 30,000 from KADET LTD which she intends to use to buy bananas to sell. She plans to use the profits from the expanded business to build a market stall.

Morine hopes to expand her business and become the leading local investor and to see her children realizing their dreams in life through education.

loans.use: To buy bananas

loans.name: Cecile

texts.en:
Cecile is 45 years old and is married with four children between the ages 7 and 15 years old.  Her husband works to  in the same medical clinic. She is a nurse and she provides medical services to the people from her area.  She employs two other nurses in her small dispensary who work in shifts to cover the full 24 hours.

Cecile would like to expand her small dispensary by adding two rooms so that she may cater to a larger number of clients. Apart from adding those two rooms, she will also try to up-grade the existing rooms by painting them.

For this reason, Cecile has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  If successful, she hopes to provide better service to her clients and, hopefully, her profits will increase.  She will continue taking care of her children by providing more food for them as well as building a secure future for them.

loans.use: To add two more rooms and renovate the existing ones

loans.name: Wibrodah Amoit

texts.en:
Wibrodah Amoit M. is a 38-year-old married woman. She is married to Peter Kalam Makuto, who is employed, and they have two children, ages 8 and 11 years old. They live in Edoret, Kenya. Wibrodah is a tailor. She has run her business for the past 7 years with good progress and profits. 

She is a new client of KADET LTD and she has applied for her first loan of KES 30,000 to enable her buy a new sewing machine. She was introduced to Kadet Ltd by a friend who is also client. 

She hopes to have an established tailoring business in the area to capture the large market demand. She also hopes to build a permanent house and see to it that her children get the best education.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 46-year-old married man living with his wife and four children. He is the main income provider for his family. He has seventeen years of experience working in sanitary projects. He takes on projects where he makes  porcelain toilets, faucets etc. in addition to his repair service. He has a large experience in this occupation. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase a new compressor and a special cutter instead of the one he is using.

In the future, he is looking to continue expansion of his business and to further increase his productivity. He expects that his business will continue to be successful in the coming year.

loans.use: to purchase a new compressor and a special cutter instead of the one he is using

loans.name: Dickson

texts.en:
Dickson is a resident of Nyamira Town in western Kenya where he has been doing mixed farming for 10 years. The milk, vegetables, eggs, and tea that he produces are sold locally and to government institutions. He lacks finances to employ farmhands.

He has requested this loan of 30,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He hopes it will transform his family and ensure the education of the children. He also has income from timber sales. In three years, he is planning to buy a vehicle to transport produce to the market.

loans.use: Purchase of and insurance for a dairy cow

loans.name: Phal

texts.en:
Phal K. is a 45-year-old single mother who currently lives in Takhmao City. She is a local chef. She is always hired by neighbors to cook meals for their wedding parties and their other ceremonies. She was married but she divorced her husband years ago. 

Phal K. is blessed with two children, and both are employed in different jobs. One of Phal K.’s kids works in a water supply company, and he always drives a car for a hundred kilometers per day. And now, her child wishes to run a new business by providing taxi service in order to earn extra profit. 

Phal K. wants to encourage her son, but she lacks fund to make it possible. To solve this obstacle, Phal K. would like to request a loan to support her son in buying a used car for running a taxi service.

loans.use: To buy a used car to use to run a taxi service

loans.name: Aminata

texts.en:
This is 25 year-old Aminata. She is married and has one 7-year-old child. Aminata's brother's wife also lives with her. 

In 2005, Aminata established her shoe business. She started her business because she wanted to be independent. Working seven days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about Le 972800 every month from this business. She would like a loan of Le 3000000 to buy more shoes. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 194560. In the future, Aminata plans to expand her business, generate more income, and acquire new assets. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy additional shoes

loans.name: Ishara Group

texts.fr: Kavira E. est entrepreneur, présidente du groupe Ishara,  âgée de 38 ans, veuve, mère de 7 enfants orphelins de père.Son mari est décédé dernièrement suite à une courte maladie. Elle fait le petit commerce de vente de divers issus de Kampala.  Elle vend  aussi la boisson locale Madrakwa. Elle  commença son business  dans sa petite jeunesse  avec son fonds propre, initiée par sa mère. Elle bénéficia de crédit de l’IMF  Hekima de 50$ en 2007. Elle installe ses produits  à son domicile. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  avec  les intrants de production boisson locale Mandrakwa (maïs, sorgho), le reste sera injecté dans le commerce de divers pour augmenter le stock en volume et en valeurs. En plus, elle ambitionne  avoir une boutique d’exposition. La cliente Kavira E. remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique. Il sied de signaler que le groupe Ishara est composé de 28 membres.
texts.en:
Kavira E. is an entrepreneur and the president of the group Ishara. She is 38 years old, widowed and the mother of seven fatherless children. Her husband died recently, following a brief illness. 

She has a small business selling a variety of goods in Kampala; she also sells the local drink "Madrakwa". She started her business when she was still young with a small loan, initiated by her mother. She obtained a loan of $50 from the micro-finance institution (MFI) Hekima in 2007. She has set-up her business at home. This new loan will be used to purchase supplies for the production of the local drink "Mandrakwa", which is made with maize and sorghum. The rest of the loan will be used for goods for her general store business, increasing the volume and value of its stock of goods. Additionally, she hopes to have a display for her shop. 

Kavira Elizabeth thanks the MFI Hekima for its work helping poor people who are are excluded from traditional banks. It should be noted that her group Ishara is comprised of 28 members.

loans.use: 2 sacks of maize, 1 sack of sorghum and goods for a general store etc.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph K. is forty-six years old and married. His wife is employed by the city council and they have three children aged between eighteen and twelve years old. His business is located at the busy Marikiti market in Nairobi. 

He sells an assortment of goods which include jackets, shoes and other items. He has been in this business for three years now.  He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is financial constraints.

 He is using his loan of Kes 50,000 to rent premises to diversify his business to shoe shining. He hopes to grow his business and become a wholesaler of shoes. He also works hard to always be able to meet his family's needs. He describes himself as intelligent, determined and God-fearing.

loans.use: Rent a shoe-shining shop

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 30 years old and is married with three children between the ages 2 and 6.  Josephine is well-known as a proven entrepreneur. She sells cosmetics and other beauty products such as body lotion. This is her second year in this business, which is open from 6 am until 6 pm every day.
 
Josephine has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to expand her business by adding more cosmetic products. Her neighborhood is the right place to sell cosmetics, because there are boarding schools in the area and many students who like to buy cosmetics. With this business expansion, Josephine will keep saving for further reinvestment in her business.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Ruth Damaris

texts.en:
Ruth Damaris O., a 41-year-old mother of three children aged 20 years, 18 years and 15 years, is married to Joseph Obanda, who is employed. They live in Eldoret-Kenya, where Ruth has been a food vendor for the past ten years with an income of KES 20,000 per month.

Ruth was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend and is now applying for her first loan of KES. 45,000. With this loan she plans to buy 5 bundles of baking flour and 30 litres of cooking oil, with the remainder being used to build a temporary hotel where she can serve her customers. She hopes to eventually operate a bigger hotel and in future extend the same services to the city centre.

loans.use: To buy 5 bundles of baking flour, 30 litres of cooking oil and  build a temporary hotel.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 27-year-old married woman and mother of four children. She is a tailor who has developed her business in her home. Her husband is the main income provider but like the majority of the Lebanese woman, she works to help him to raise their big family.  

She presents sewing services and she also repairs clothes. Today, she is requesting to borrow $800 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase a new sewing machine. That will allow her to increase her production and furthermore deliver her tailored garments faster. She is able to serve a wide range of clients from her home. In the future, she is looking to expand her business and eventually open her own tailoring shop.

loans.use: to purchase a new sewing machine

loans.name: Baterdene

texts.en: Baterdene D. is 30 years old and lives with his parents and siblings in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia’s capital city. He and his family live together in their own house. His parents are both retired and all his siblings work. Since 2005, he has been operating a taxi service using his own car. He used his previous loan to complete building his house where the family lives.  He is planning to start a new, meat trading business and therefore he is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to start this business.

loans.use: To start his business

loans.name: Henriette

texts.en:
Henriette is 46 years old and married with four children aged between 12 and 20. She sells honey in Nyamagabe district in Rwanda. She has been in business for ten years and works from 6am until 7pm.

This is her first loan requested through Vision Finance Company and she plans to buy more products for getting delicious honey. The extra income from this loan will help her to pay school fees for their children in the future.

She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more honey to sell

loans.name: Teresa Anyoso

texts.en:
Teresa Anyoso E. is a hardworking, 44-year-old woman. She is married and the mother of four children ages 18 years, 16 years, 10 years, and 8 years. She has been selling fresh maize for the past 15 years and she earns a monthly income of KES. 10,000.

She learned about KADET LTD and registered as one of our clients. She has no previous credit history with any other MFI. She has now applied for her first loan of KES. 35,000 from KADET LTD to purchase more maize to sell. She will also use part of the money to build a stall to store the maize.

Teresa hopes to expand her business and become the leading local investor in Eldoret, Kenya and to see her children realizing their dreams in life through education.

loans.use: To purchase more fresh maize and build grain storage

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is a resident of Nyamira Town in western Kenya and has been doing mixed farming for 13 years. He sells the milk, tea, beans, maize and nappier grass that he produces to the government and locally.

He has requested a loan of 45,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He hopes the loan will provide income enough to build a new home for his family. He also plans to expand his land with funds from his poshomill (cereal-grinding machine) business.

He says funds are the limitation and wishes he could get more.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Say

texts.en:
Mrs. Say B. earns a living by raising pigs in a pigpen behind her house. She raises them both for their offspring and for slaughter. Her husband also helps her in the same business, and he is a liquor maker as well, earning an income of approximately $3 per day. The couple has three children; all of them are single, living under their care. 

Say B. has raised a lot of piglets and she had hoped to sell them to buyers four months after she began raising them. Unfortunately, the pigs are not big enough, due to the lack of food. To help solve this problem, Mrs. Say B. has requested a loan of $1,100 that she will use to buy several sacks of pig feed to fatten her pigs, with the rest of loan going towards the purchase of a few small pigs to feed.

loans.use: To buy several sacks of pig feed to fatten her pigs, and to purchase a few small pigs to feed

loans.name: Yuvenciah

texts.en:
Yuvenciah is a resident of Nyamira Town in western Kenya. She is married and has 6 children. She does mixed farming. She produces maize, bananas, milk, beans, sorghum, and tea, and sells them to the local market.

She has applied for this loan of 45,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She gets additional income from her retail shop where she makes an average of 10,000 KES monthly in the local market. She intends to save the income from the loan to buy a truck and venture into transportation of milk, tea, and animal feed.

She is focused on running a wholesale business in the future.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Jackline Kayeke

texts.en:
Jackline Kayeke I. is a 31-year-old single woman who lives in Eldoret, Kenya. She knits and sells the products to her customers at a profit. She has been in this business for 6 years and earns a monthly profit of KES. 5,000.

Jackline learned about KADET LTD through one of our credit officers and she is now applying for her third loan of KES. 35,000. She intends to buy a knitting machine to make the work easier and more efficient so she does not delay her customer’s orders. She plans to use the anticipated profits to expand her business.

In the future, Jackline wishes to live a better and a more comfortable life.

loans.use: To buy a knitting machine

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 48-year-old single woman living with her mother and one brother.  She has owned a small grocery store since 1997. Her store is located in a busy area so she has been able, over the years, to gain a good number of customers among those passing by her shop. She cooperates with her brother to provide better life conditions for their family. 

Today, she is requesting to borrow $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to increase her store’s inventory. She expects that her business will continue to grow in the coming year. 

It is very common in Lebanon to find small supermarkets selling perishable and non-perishable goods. As members of the communities themselves, store owners have a deep understanding of local consumer needs and can offer products that meet local demands. The strong network of community relationships are an important component of life in Lebanon, especially in smaller towns and villages.

loans.use: to increase her store inventory

loans.name: Seraphine

texts.en:
Seraphine is 31 years old and is married with two children, who are one and three years old.  She has a clean and well-stocked store, where she sells a large variety of groceries and other items. She has been in this business for six years. Her store is located in Gikongoro district in Rwanda.  

Seraphine has requested this loan to expand her stock. With any profits Seraphine makes from this loan, she will reinvest into the business and continue to increase her business.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items for resale

loans.name: Elizabeth Akinyi

texts.en:
Elizabeth Akinyi O. is 44 years old. She is married to Erick Odeny who is employed. Her business is a source of additional income for the family. They have four children, ages 23, 20, 16 and 12 years old. 

Elizabeth sells second-hand clothes door-to-door ("hawking"). This has been her work for the past 15 years and she earns a monthly profit of KES. 20,000.

Elizabeth learned about KADET LTD through a marketing awareness campaign in the area. She is applying for her first loan of KES. 43,000. She intends to restock her clothes business and build a temporary boutique stall. The anticipated profits will be used to purchase a plot of land.

In the future, Elizabeth wishes to expand her business by buying more bales of clothes and also to have rental houses. Her deeper desire is to see her children realizing their goals in life through better education.

loans.use: To restock her clothing business and build a temporary boutique stall

loans.name: Flaurentine

texts.en:
Flaurentine is 35 years old and is married with four children. She runs a hotel in Taba district in Rwanda.  She and her husband both work hard in order to get all of the basic needs for their family.  Flaurentine has been running her hotel for six years, and it is well-known and organized.  She works from 6am until 8pm every day.

Flaurentine has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her hotel. Flaurentine will use this loan to purchase additional products like beer and goat. With any profit, Flaurentine plans to continue to increase her business.

loans.use: To buy more goat and beer to serve to clients.

loans.name: Baterdene

texts.en:
Baterdene D. is 47 years old and lives with his wife in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia’s capital city. He and his wife live in their own house. He is divorced from his previous wife and his children live with their mother. Since 2008, he has been operating a taxi service using his own car, after working in the government agency for several years. He plans to fix his house and improve his family's standard of living. 

Baterdene is requesting a 800,000 MNT loan to purchase spare parts for his car and remodel his house.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for his car

loans.name: Marie Chantal

texts.en:
Marie Chantal is 22 years old and married, but they have no children. She runs a tailoring business in the market where she sews different clothes, such as dresses, skirts, trousers, etc. She has been running this business for two years and works from 7am until 5pm during the week.

Marie Chantal has requested her first loan from Kiva via Vision Finance Company to purchase more sewing materials. The extra income she makes from this loan will help her save for her future.

She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase more sewing materials

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan K., 48 years old, is married to Jackson Chimirmir, 50, and they have five children. She runs a posho (grinding) mill where she mills maize into flour for neighbors at a fee. She has been in business for four years, and her monthly income from the business is Kshs 10,000. She also gets additional income from the sale of milk from her dairy cows.

Susan is requesting a loan of Kshs 39,000 from KADET with which she plans to purchase more maize stock for milling and expand her business. She anticipates some profit which she will use to expand her business and revive her small retail shop (kiosk). Susan's dreams are to grow in business, become a supplier of flour, and even buy a pick-up truck for transportation.

loans.use: To purchase stock

loans.name: Chanda

texts.en:
Chanda H. is from the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 34 years old. Chanda is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Chanda owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling ready-to-wear clothing like t-shirts, short pants, long pants, jackets, and underwear in the local community. Chanda has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Chanda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Chanda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to buy and sell. Chanda is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Chanda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon is 25 years old and single. He sells clothing, shoes, bags, etc. His store is open from 7am until 6pm every day. He runs this business in Gasaka district in Rwanda.
